designScenario.description: The HF Communication System is engineered for long-range, high-frequency communication in a hazardous operational environment. Modeled after sophisticated avionics systems, it supports multi-modal data, voice, and telemetry exchange with secure transmission and advanced redundancy. The system ensures robust electromagnetic compatibility and interference rejection to meet rigorous aviation safety standards.
designScenario.name: HF Communication System

details.description: The system shall support multi-modal communication encompassing voice, data, and telemetry analogous to aircraft intercom and ACARS systems.
Must maintain a real-time data exchange with latency below 50 milliseconds ensuring prompt communications during critical flight operations.
Requires high throughput capabilities exceeding 100 Mbps even under high electromagnetic interference conditions.
Implement advanced encryption and secure transmission protocols to prevent unauthorized access and data breaches, mirroring secured air-to-ground channels.
Include fail-safe mechanisms and redundant communication paths to guarantee operational safety during component failures.
The system’s user interface and management software shall be intuitive, enabling ground control and maintenance crews to perform diagnostics and upgrades seamlessly.
Software must support over-the-air updates and remote troubleshooting to ensure high maintainability in line with aviation regulatory requirements.

relationships.description: The Transceiver Module communicates bi-directionally with the Antenna Array to transmit and receive HF signals, akin to cockpit-to-tower radio links.
The Signal Processor aggregates RF inputs from the Transceiver Module and prepares data for secure encryption, reflecting the data conditioning process in avionics.
The Encryption Module depends on processed raw data from the Signal Processor to perform encryption before transmission.
The Control Unit orchestrates the entire HF communication process by delegating tasks to subordinate modules such as the Transceiver Module, similar to an aircraft’s flight management system.
All modules, including the Control Unit and submodules, depend on the Power Supply to receive stable and redundant electrical power similar to an aircraft's auxiliary power unit.
